2_1AZjDLkfYwSmjM7ZJUf7HHnrF778augRMa.body: Ah great, more of the "only evil people use Tor" mantra. Does better encryption and privacy allow people to access things like CP? yes it does, but that's the price of freedom.

Honestly, I'd much rather the devs work on improving and testing the security/encryption rather than trying to start censoring content. There are two reasons behind this, A) If the crypto and security is good enough, others won't know that you're hosting potentially illegal content in the first place and B) Sure, most people can agree that censoring CP is reasonable, but that starts a slippery slope towards more censorship. First against things which aren't actually illegal, just questionable or representing opinions that others don't like, then suppressing unwanted content.

> [paintninja](#comment_11_12EgeG4vgNHzuPJYZqVJQwy2W9vkywbQQu): Personally I'm happy with ZeroNet's security and encryption. I just wish they would add gzip support so the bandwidth and storage requirements aren't so high... If we had gzip support on ZeroNet we would likely have much higher storage allowances on sites like this one and ZeroMail. And as an added bonus, zites would download faster on first-time visits.
> I don't see ZeroNet aiming to be an entirely anonymous solution, and I'm fine with that. I myself would prefer having some moderation by pseudo-anonymity rather than people feeling like they can do whatever they want with no consequences. I don't even want to accidentally come across stuff like the op mentions, once I see it I might not be able to unsee it.

If you don't want anonymity and privacy go back to the clearnet. The whole point of making something decentralized is to avoid censorship and increase privacy as no central organization or company can decide to reveal who you are or tell you what you can do.

> [paintninja](#comment_12_12EgeG4vgNHzuPJYZqVJQwy2W9vkywbQQu): But I like the benefits that decentralized networking brings outside of anonymity. Having sites consistently load instantly after my first visit while still always being up-to-date, being able to view them offline seamlessly, being able to start up my own website without any special software or cost, never having my site crash due to unexpected load or being inaccessible when my server's down. Never having to need an email and verify it just to make an account, never having to login everywhere with separate accounts to do simple things like write a comment... ZeroNet does so much more than the current clearnet can.

Then you better learn to live that some people can and will use it for things you disagree with.
